channel.title: NPR Topics: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Why some ant colonies get tricked into killing their own queens
item.description: For some would-be ant queens, the easiest way to take over a colony is to dupe its worker ants into committing regicide.
item.content:encoded:
For some would-be ant queens, the easiest way to take over a colony is to dupe its worker ants into committing regicide.

(Image credit: Joachim K. Löckener, CC BY-SA 3.0)
item.dc:creator: Nell Greenfieldboyce

item.title: Disaster and insurance costs are rising. The middle class is struggling to hang on
item.description: Middle-class families are struggling to afford insurance in southwest Florida. Realtors say a wave of foreclosures could be coming.
item.content:encoded:
Middle-class families are struggling to afford insurance in southwest Florida. Realtors say a wave of foreclosures could be coming.

(Image credit: Ryan Kellman)
item.dc:creator: Michael Copley

item.title: A guerrilla gardener installed a pop-up wetland in the LA River. Here's how — and why
item.description: Well-meaning city dwellers forgo permits and official procedure to rewild urban areas across the country. In downtown LA, artist Doug Rosenberg is trying to push the grassroots movement forward.
item.content:encoded:
Well-meaning city dwellers forgo permits and official procedure to rewild urban areas across the country. In downtown LA, artist Doug Rosenberg is trying to push the grassroots movement forward.

(Image credit: Courtney Theophin/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Deal restores Cornell's federal grants, reviving research on infant artificial heart
item.description: After a deal with the White House, researchers at Cornell will receive their federal grants. For one scientist, that means resuming work on an implantable artificial heart for babies and toddlers.
item.content:encoded: After a deal with the White House, researchers at Cornell will receive their federal grants. For one scientist, that means resuming work on an implantable artificial heart for babies and toddlers.
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: China's astronauts land safely after space debris collision
item.description: Three Chinese astronauts are back on earth after they had to prolong their stay in outer space due to space debris hitting their spacecraft.
item.content:encoded: Three Chinese astronauts are back on earth after they had to prolong their stay in outer space due to space debris hitting their spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: As funding falters, young brain scientists rethink careers in research
item.description: Research on brain disorders may slow as young neuroscientists struggle to find jobs and research grants.
item.content:encoded:
Research on brain disorders may slow as young neuroscientists struggle to find jobs and research grants.

(Image credit: Cemile Bingol/Digital Vision Vectors)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: How to scare off hungry gulls
item.description: Neeltje Boogert, an associate professor at the University of Exeter in the U.K., is the senior author of a new scientific study about how to best scare away gulls, out now from the Royal Society.
item.content:encoded: Neeltje Boogert, an associate professor at the University of Exeter in the U.K., is the senior author of a new scientific study about how to best scare away gulls, out now from the Royal Society.
item.dc:creator: Brianna Scott

item.title: Scientists pull ancient RNA from a woolly mammoth's body
item.description: Scientists have extracted the oldest RNA molecules out of a woolly mammoth, gaining a snapshot into the processes at work in the extinct mammal's body just before it died.
item.content:encoded:
Scientists have extracted the oldest RNA molecules out of a woolly mammoth, gaining a snapshot into the processes at work in the extinct mammal's body just before it died.

(Image credit: Valeri Plotnikov)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: This week in science: A Saturn moon's ocean, chameleon eyes and energy used for AI
item.description: Emily Kwong and Regina Barber of NPR's Short Wave discuss new findings about the ocean of Saturn's moon Enceladus, the secrets behind chameleons' eye movements and the energy use behind AI computing.
item.content:encoded: Emily Kwong and Regina Barber of NPR's Short Wave discuss new findings about the ocean of Saturn's moon Enceladus, the secrets behind chameleons' eye movements and the energy use behind AI computing.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong

item.title: Why home insurance is unaffordable, even in places without wildfires or hurricanes
item.description: Some of the country's highest home insurance prices are in the central U.S., a region generally considered to be protected from climate-driven disasters such as wildfires and hurricanes.
item.content:encoded:
Some of the country's highest home insurance prices are in the central U.S., a region generally considered to be protected from climate-driven disasters such as wildfires and hurricanes.

(Image credit: Rebecca Hersher)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Hersher
